awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Research and Education in Multiscale Sensing and Imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site program at Iowa State University, offers state-of-the-art, multi-disciplinary research experiences in the areas of sensing, actuation and imaging, to diverse and talented cohorts of undergraduates from institutions with limited or no research opportunities. The need for advanced sensing and imaging technologies to enhance our nation's health, homeland, food and energy security has never been more urgent as evident from the NAE Grand Challenges.  Research in sensing and imaging technologies has an obvious societal impact that appeals to a broad demographic of students. In addition, the multidisciplinary nature of the research, which merges engineering concepts with those in the sciences will help attract students from all engineering and non-engineering disciplines. This REU Site with a focus on sensing and imaging research will take advantage of shared research interests and synergistic interactions of the faculty to help increase graduate enrollment. The student experience will evolve from dependent to independent status and will enable them to acquire life-long skills that will impact their contributions to science and engineering and to society.

The primary goal of this renewal REU Site program is to provide each undergraduate participant with a ten-week scientifically rigorous, intellectually demanding, research experience within a highly collegial environment of collaboration with faculty and other students. The program focuses on the development of the technical skills and critical-thinking abilities of the participants and on their exposure to substantive, representative research investigations related to design and manufacturing of sensors, actuators and smart materials; state-of-the-art imaging and diagnostic systems and data driven approaches to sensor/device design and reliability. Project topics include microfluidic devices, nanomechanical sensors for biological agents; nanoenergetics imaging, bioprosthetics, nanomaterials synthesis, and reliability of implantable sensors. The program will also include weekly seminar series; short courses; communication workshops; interactions with middle school teachers; organized social and cultural events designed to complement the research activities; a REU Research Symposium to provide feedback on student work and exceptional achievement; and training in ethical implications of engineering that will be conducted by ISU's Bioethics program.  Participants will also be encouraged to present a technical paper/poster at regional and national conferences within one year of participating in this program.

This site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The MoSAIc program over three NSF grants and 10 cohorts has provided a 10-week research experience for 108 students from institutions that have minimum opportunities for advanced engineering research. The program attracted an average of ~100 applicants each year. Participating students came from our targeted pool of 1) Four-year colleges in the midwest that have a minimum opportunity for advanced engineering research: Central College, Dordt College, St. Cloud State, Truman State, U Wisconsin (Eau Claire), U Wisconsin (Stout), St. Olaf College, Gustavus Adolphus College and Murray State U (KY); 2) Community college students from Iowa CC over the last five summers including Des Moines Area CC, Marshalltown CC, Kirkwood CC;  3) National institutions serving minority students: U Arkansas-Pine Bluff, Savannah State University (GA), St. Joaquim Delta College and University of Puerto Rico-Mayaguez and 4) Incoming URM and women freshman to ISU recruited through the College of Engineering's recruiting programs. The program was successful in engaging a very diverse and talented cohort in the program ? 52% URM students, 33% women, and 20% CC students.

As of this writing, student participants over the first ten summer cohorts have produced fourteen publications in high-impact journals and more than 25 technical presentations at regional, national, and international conferences  The student participants have also won several awards based on presentations of research.

The research performed by students has led to the development of computational tools for the design of organic photovoltaic devices and solar cells, ultrasound-based techniques to selectively destroy harmful biofilms, high-resolution cantilever-based sensing mechanisms for biochemical species, and the development of calibration techniques for high-speed 3D optical imaging systems. Several REU students have won awards for research performed as part of the MoSAIc REU.

MoSAIc REU successfully recruited students for graduate or advanced degrees at ISU. 40 of the 108 REU alums joined ISU for an advanced or graduate degree, with 25% of 4-year college alums, 74% of CC-alums, 30% of female Alums, 40% of male alums, 42% of URM alums, and 30% of non-URM alums joining ISU for graduate or advanced STEM degree after the REU experience.

     Overall, the MoSAIc program enhances students' engagement with STEM; nearly half of the students in a STEM field are either pursuing or have received an advanced degree. Community college students are enrolling to complete a 4-year program after their associate degrees, and nearly 40% are pursuing an advanced degree.

 


Last Modified: 01/23/2023
Modified by: Pranav Shrotriya
